emails.subject: Wing test needed ASAP!
emails.body: Hey, Flairbus are on my back about their latest wing design. I need you to send over the first natural frequency by tomorrow. I'd recommend estimating frequency from the unforced time-domain response. Have a look in your toolkit and see what you can do.

results.name: First natural frequency
results.praise: Nice one! The client will be pleased with such a quick turnaround.

feedback.message: Hmm, your measured natural frequency is not quite right. Remember, frequency is 1/T, where T is the period of a single oscillation.
Not quite. Remember that period is the time between two peaks in the time domain.
Our in-house testing gives a first natural frequency of 150 Hz. This corresponds to a period of 0.01 seconds.

emails.subject: Modal test data needed
emails.body: I need a quick and rough estimate of the first three natural frequencies of the wing before my next stakeholder meeting. Please setup a test (NOTE: the wing is too stiff to execute free vibration testing in this case) and measure the second natural frequency. Time is of the essence!

results.name: Experimental setup
results.praise: Great! A hammer test provides a quick and simple test considering the constraints of the task. You also correctly selected the tip hardness which enabled excitation of the all required modes.

feedback.message: One or more of the parameters in your test setup is incorrect. Focus on the excitation method.
Given that Hammer testing should be used, which tip hardness enables excitation of the greatest number of modes?
Hard tip hammer testing is ideal as it is quick to execute (does not require a shaker) and excites all required modes.

results.name: Second natural frequency
results.praise: Correct! You successfully setup an appropriate test and employed the discrete Fourier transform.

feedback.message: That doesn't seem to match our simulations. Make sure you are using Hammer testing.
Not quite, make sure you are reading the correct peak off the DFT graph.
Our in-house testing gives a second natural frequency of 150 Hz. This is approximately the position of the second peak in the DFT.

emails.subject: Modelling vibration caused by engine
emails.body: In an aircraft wing, the engine (which vibrates a lot!) is usually located at the middle of the wing. We need you to conduct a modal test to simulate the dynamics.

results.name: Experimental setup
results.praise: Nice one! You have setup the test correctly.

feedback.message: Not quite, make sure you are exciting the structure from where the engine would be located.
Check the tooltip. There are some constraints on sampling frequency.
The correct excitation location is at l/2. Sampling is limited to 512 Hz in this case.

results.name: Run a few tests with this setup. What error might you be introducing by limiting sampling to 512 Hz?
results.praise: Correct! Aliasing occurs when the signal contains frequency content at greater than half the sampling frequency.

feedback.message: Unfortunately that is not correct. Remember that your sampling frequency should always more than twice the Nyquist frequency.
Unfortunately that is not correct.
Aliasing is the correct answer. Aliasing occurs when the signal contains frequency content at greater than half the sampling frequency.

emails.subject: We need modal damping ratios!
emails.body: Hello, I've heard big things about your modal testing expertise. Please can you produce a Nyquist plot and use it to estimate modal damping ratios?

results.name: Radius of the circle
results.praise: That is correct! Since the circle is centred on the real axis and starts from the origin, the radius is simply the x-value of the centre coordinate.

feedback.message: Not quite, maybe try a different excitation method to produce a higher resolution Nyquist plot.
Unfortunately that is not correct. Try using Sine sweep with maximum sampling frequency.
Our finite element simulations give a radius of 20. Since the circle is centred on the real axis and starts from the origin, the radius is simply the x-value of the centre coordinate.

results.name: Third natural frequency
results.praise: Well done! The natural frequency is where the mobility Nyquist plot crosses the real axis. This is also where the sweep rate is at its maximum.

feedback.message: Not quite, look for the frequency where the sweep rate is at its maximum.
Try reading off the frequency where the circle crosses the real axis.
The third natural frequency should be roughly 200 Hz. The natural frequency is where the mobility Nyquist plot crosses the real axis. This is also where the sweep rate is at its maximum.

results.name: Third modal damping ratio
results.praise: Spot on! This is the most accurate estimate of zeta from the plot.

feedback.message: It might be easier to find the angle subtended from the origin to the point of interest and use angle identities.
Use the pair of points closest to the resonance point for more accurate estimate of damping.
The third modal damping ratio is expected to be around 20% using the half-power method.

emails.subject: Mode shapes on my desk by this afternoon
emails.body: Hello, we've just had some new clients adopt the Flairbus wing design and they're encountering issues with large wing tip deflections when the engine is at 3l/4. Given that the engine is rotating at 9000 rpm, identify which mode this is likely to be exciting. Then we need an estimate for the mode shape of this mode ASAP. I'd recommend starting by producing a Bode plot. Mode shapes can be found by the ratios of the gain peaks at different measurement locations. Good luck, we're depending on you here!

results.name: Mode of vibration
results.praise: Perfect! The engine is rotating at 9000 rpm = 150 Hz which is approximately the second natural frequency.

feedback.message: Double check that you're converting your units of rotational speed to Hz.
Try a different excitation method when estimating natural frequency.

results.name: Experimental setup
results.praise: Correct! You have setup the test correctly to measure accelerations in the second mode of vibration.

feedback.message: Pick an excitation method which can best isolate the second mode.
Double check the placement of your accelerometers.

results.name: Second mode shape
results.praise: Perfect! Our finite element models agree with this observation.

feedback.message: Try a few different excitation methods and see which produces the least noisy mode shape plot.
Remember to consider phase changes. If two locations are pi radians out of phase, their signs will be opposite.

results.name: Second modal damping ratio
results.praise: Perfect! Our finite element models agree with this observation.

feedback.message: Try a few different excitation methods and see which produces the least noisy Bode plot.
Remember there are two different methods to obtain modal damping ratios. If you are struggling with half power, maybe try circle fitting.

results.name: You may have noticed signifcant noise in the DFT. What might be causing this problem?
options: The recorded time-domain signals are not periodic over the DFT window.
The application of a digital filter has removed useful frequency components as well as noise.
results.answer: The recorded time-domain signals are not periodic over the DFT window.
results.praise: Correct! Leakage occurs when the time-domain signal is not periodic over the DFT window. This can result in the appearance of frequency peaks which, in reality, are not present in the measured time-domain signal.
